title: Shaun Maloney
text:
Shaun Richard Maloney (born 24 January 1983) is a Scottish <a href="Association%20football">football</a> coach and former player, who is the current manager of <a href="Scottish%20Premiership">Scottish Premiership</a> side <a href="Hibernian%20F.C.">Hibernian</a>. Maloney played for <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a>, <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a>, <a href="Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.">Wigan Athletic</a>, <a href="Chicago%20Fire%20Soccer%20Club">Chicago Fire</a>, <a href="Hull%20City%20A.F.C.">Hull City</a> and the <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland national team</a> as an <a href="Midfielder%23Winger">attacking midfielder</a> or <a href="Midfielder%23Winger">winger</a>. After retiring as a player, Maloney worked for Celtic and the <a href="Belgium%20national%20football%20team">Belgium national team</a> as a coach. He was appointed Hibernian manager in December 2021.
Maloney started his career at Celtic, playing 215 matches across all competitions and winning honours including five <a href="Scottish%20Premier%20League">Scottish Premier League</a> titles. He was the first player to claim both the <a href="SPFA%20Players%27%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">SPFA Players' Player of the Year</a> and the <a href="PFA%20Scotland%20Young%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">SPFA Young Player of the Year</a> awards in the same season, doing so in 2005/06. He had a spell in the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> with <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a>, before returning for a second spell at Celtic. Maloney returned to English football in 2011 with <a href="Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.">Wigan Athletic</a>, helping them win the <a href="2013%20FA%20Cup%20Final">2013 FA Cup Final</a>. Maloney then briefly played in <a href="Major%20League%20Soccer">Major League Soccer</a> for <a href="Chicago%20Fire%20Soccer%20Club">Chicago Fire</a>. He last played for <a href="Hull%20City%20A.F.C.">Hull City</a> for two seasons, before retiring due to injury in 2017. Maloney made his senior international debut for <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> in 2005 and he went on to earn 47 caps, scoring seven goals.
Early life.
Maloney was born to an English father and Scottish mother in <a href="Miri">Miri</a>, a coastal city in north-eastern <a href="Sarawak">Sarawak</a>, Malaysia, on 24 January 1983. He spent his infancy in Malaysia while his father, a helicopter pilot and armed forces veteran, worked there as a flying instructor. The family returned to Britain when Maloney was five years old, after his father accepted a job in <a href="Aberdeen">Aberdeen</a>, Scotland. In a 2014 interview, Maloney said: "Although I am Scottish and play for Scotland, Malaysia will always be a special part of me."
Maloney was educated at <a href="List%20of%20schools%20in%20Aberdeen">St Joseph's Primary School</a> and <a href="Cults%20Academy">Cults Academy</a> in <a href="Aberdeen">Aberdeen</a>.
At age of 10, he had joined his first football club, Kincorth Boys' Club. At 12, he moved to Culter Boys' Club then at 14, to Albion Boys' Club.
It was revealed in 2013, that as a youngster Maloney had played tennis regularly against future World Number 1, <a href="Andy%20Murray">Andy Murray</a>.
Playing career.
Celtic.
After joining <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> as a <a href="trainee">trainee</a> in 1999, Maloney made his first team debut on 29 April 2001 against <a href="Rangers%20F.C.">Rangers</a> at <a href="Ibrox%20Stadium">Ibrox Stadium</a>, in a 3–0 win for Celtic. He spent the next few years trying to break into the first team, spending most of his time as a <a href="Substitute%20%28association%20football%29">substitute</a>. Despite not playing regularly, Maloney acquired a reputation for being a free kick specialist. Maloney did appear several times for Celtic during their run to the UEFA Cup Final in 2003, and scored in a 3–1 win over <a href="VfB%20Stuttgart">VfB Stuttgart</a> at Parkhead in the Round of 16.
In February 2004, Maloney picked up a <a href="cruciate%20ligament">cruciate ligament</a> injury. He returned from the injury late in <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20Celtic%20F.C.%20season">season 2004–05</a>, starting only one game in that season.
Maloney hit top form for Celtic in the <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20Celtic%20F.C.%20season">2005–06 season</a>, after being moved from a striking position to the left of midfield by manager <a href="Gordon%20Strachan">Gordon Strachan</a>. His displays received praise from players, fans and the media throughout the year, and in recognition of his excellent season he was awarded both the <a href="Scottish%20PFA%20Players%27%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">SPFA Player of the Year</a> and <a href="PFA%20Scotland%20Young%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">Young Player of the Year</a> awards, the first time a player has won both plaudits in the same season. He also won Celtic Fans' Player of the Year, and Players Player of the Year in a season which saw him score 16 goals and contribute 28 assists from midfield.
With his contract expiring at the end of the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20Celtic%20F.C.%20season">2006–07 season</a>, Celtic moved to offer Maloney a new deal. However, contract negotiations continued for months, constantly breaking down due to differences between the two parties. Chief Executive <a href="Peter%20Lawwell">Peter Lawwell</a> asserted that Celtic "cannot keep players at any cost" while Maloney warned that "In situations like this one, both parties have to be completely happy with the outcome." He also promised that the prolonged contract talks would not affect his football and that he hoped he would not have to consider leaving the club in the future.
Maloney would have been able to leave Celtic for free in the summer of 2007, by signing a pre-contract agreement with another club. No new contract was agreed with Celtic, and they subsequently agreed a £1 million transfer to Aston Villa. In his first tenure, Maloney made a total of 139 appearances for the Hoops in all competitions, scoring 37 times.
Aston Villa.
Just before the <a href="transfer%20window">transfer window</a> closed on 31 January 2007, Maloney signed a pre-contract agreement with Aston Villa. Villa manager <a href="Martin%20O%27Neill">Martin O'Neill</a>, who managed him at Celtic, was keen to bring Maloney to Villa for the second half of the season however and moments before the deadline he signed for the Midlands club for a reported fee of £1 million. He made his debut in the 2–0 defeat at <a href="Reading%20F.C.">Reading</a> on 10 February 2007 On 28 April 2007, Maloney scored his first Villa goal in a victory against <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Man City</a> at the <a href="City%20of%20Manchester%20Stadium">City of Manchester Stadium</a> from a free kick which was curled around the wall into the bottom right of the goal.
Maloney had trouble settling into the club but after a somewhat lacklustre start to his Villa career, he began to show his best form. Maloney has acknowledged that his football had been suffering but remained optimistic about his future at the club: "Homesickness has affected my form. I haven't played well enough to play in the team and I think that has shown, so hopefully now things can change." Both O'Neill and teammate <a href="Stiliyan%20Petrov">Stiliyan Petrov</a>, who were both at Celtic during Maloney's time there, had expressed their desire for Maloney to stay at the club despite reports linking him with a move back to Scotland.
Maloney scored a brace for Aston Villa in a 4–4 draw with Chelsea at <a href="Stamford%20Bridge%20%28stadium%29">Stamford Bridge</a> on <a href="Boxing%20Day">Boxing Day</a> 2007. However, after that Maloney did not play a lot of matches as half of his last season appearances were substitutions, and he also said that he would like to one day go back and play in Scotland.
Return to Celtic.
On 22 August 2008, <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> announced the signing of Maloney on a four-year deal for a fee of £3 million. Maloney marked his return with a Man of the Match performance and two assists in his first match, after coming off the bench for <a href="Jan%20Vennegoor%20of%20Hesselink">Jan Vennegoor of Hesselink</a> in a 3–0 victory over <a href="Falkirk%20F.C.">Falkirk</a> at <a href="Celtic%20Park">Celtic Park</a>. Maloney scored his first goal after his return to Celtic in a 4–2 away win over <a href="Motherwell%20F.C.">Motherwell</a> and managed his second the following week in a 3–1 away win at <a href="Kilmarnock%20F.C.">Kilmarnock</a>. He finished the season with five goals, taking his total Celtic goals tally to 42.
Under new manager <a href="Tony%20Mowbray">Tony Mowbray</a>, Maloney played in 17 of Celtic's first 18 fixtures of season 2009–10. However he began having trouble with his <a href="Achilles%20tendon">Achilles tendon</a> after the 2–1 defeat against Rangers on 4 October 2009. Maloney played a further four matches after that, but was substituted at half-time in Celtic's League Cup defeat against Hearts. It was revealed he was suffering from <a href="Achilles%20tendinitis">Achilles tendinitis</a>, and he did not play another game that season.
Maloney started the 2010–11 season in good form with goals against <a href="St%20Mirren%20F.C.">St Mirren</a>, <a href="Heart%20of%20Midlothian%20F.C.">Hearts</a> and a brace against <a href="Hamilton%20Academical%20F.C.">Hamilton</a>. After this run of form, Maloney was given the short-term captaincy of Celtic in the absence of <a href="Scott%20Brown%20%28footballer%2C%20born%20June%201985%29">Scott Brown</a> through injury. However, fitness problems flared up again for Maloney in November 2010 when he injured his ankle during a league match against <a href="Inverness%20Caledonian%20Thistle%20F.C.">Inverness CT</a>. He required to undergo ankle surgery in December, and didn't return to the first team until April 2011. Maloney featured in eight of Celtic's remaining matches; scoring against <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.">Aberdeen</a> in the Scottish Cup semi-final and then against <a href="Motherwell%20F.C.">Motherwell</a> in the last league fixture of the season.
Wigan Athletic.
Maloney joined <a href="Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.">Wigan Athletic</a> in the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> on 31 August 2011 for a fee of £850,000, signing a three-year deal. He made his debut on 13 September 2011 in a 2–1 defeat against <a href="Crystal%20Palace%20F.C.">Crystal Palace</a> in the <a href="Football%20League%20Cup">League Cup</a>. He struggled to break into the first team, appearing three times as a substitute during the first half of the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Premier%20League">2011–12 season</a>. Maloney admitted his fitness "was lacking a little bit" when he joined the club, and manager <a href="Roberto%20Mart%C3%ADnez">Roberto Martínez</a> felt that Maloney needed more time to settle-in. On 11 March 2012, he made his first Premier League appearance in almost five months, coming on as a substitute against <a href="Norwich%20City%20F.C.">Norwich City</a>. His performance was described as "outstanding", and he was rewarded with his first league start for the club in the following game against <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a>. On 24 March 2012, he scored a penalty against <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> at <a href="Anfield">Anfield</a> in a 1–2 win for Wigan – his first goal for the club. Maloney topped this effort with a wonderful curling goal against <a href="Manchester%20United">Manchester United</a> on 11 April, lifting his side out of the relegation zone for the first time since October with a 1–0 win. Then, on 28 April 2012, Maloney scored Wigan's third goal in an emphatic 4–0 home win over fourth placed <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle</a>.
On 17 January 2013, it was announced that Maloney signed a new contract with Wigan Athletic, keeping him at the club until 2015.
On 7 April 2013, Maloney scored a 94th minute free kick goal, seconds from the end of the <a href="Queens%20Park%20Rangers%20F.C.">QPR</a> match at <a href="Loftus%20Road">Loftus Road</a> which earned Wigan Athletic a valuable point in their race to once again escape from <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> relegation. Six days later, on 13 April 2013, Maloney scored Wigan Athletic's first goal in the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> semi-final at <a href="Wembley">Wembley</a> against <a href="Millwall%20F.C.">Millwall</a>, with a volley on the 25th minute and was voted man of the match, guiding Wigan Athletic to their first ever <a href="FA%20Cup%20Final">FA Cup Final</a>. On 11 May 2013 Maloney won the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> with Wigan, playing the whole game and assisting the only goal of the match in a 1–0 upset win against <a href="Manchester%20City">Manchester City</a>. However, only three days later, Wigan were relegated from the Premier League following a 4–1 defeat against Arsenal at the <a href="Emirates%20Stadium">Emirates Stadium</a>.
Chicago Fire.
On 25 January 2015, Maloney signed for <a href="Major%20League%20Soccer">Major League Soccer</a> side <a href="Chicago%20Fire%20Soccer%20Club">Chicago Fire</a> for an undisclosed fee. He was signed as one of the team's <a href="Designated%20Player%20Rule">Designated Players</a>. On 4 April 2015, Maloney scored his first goal for Fire in a 3–2 win over <a href="FC%20Toronto">Toronto</a> at <a href="Toyota%20Park">Toyota Park</a>, and went on to win <a href="2015%20Major%20League%20Soccer%20season%23Weekly%20awards">MLS player of the week</a> honours.
Hull City.
After only eight months in Chicago, Maloney signed a two-year contract with <a href="Hull%20City%20A.F.C.">Hull City</a> on 27 August 2015. Maloney was transferred for an undisclosed fee.
He made his debut on 29 August 2015 in the home match against <a href="Preston%20North%20End%20F.C.">Preston North End</a> which City won 2–0. Maloney came off the bench to score his first goal, on 21 November 2015, in a 1–1 draw away to <a href="Bristol%20City%20F.C.">Bristol City</a>.
His contract with Hull expired after the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20in%20English%20football">2016–17</a> season. Maloney discussed terms with <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.">Aberdeen</a>, but a hernia injury prevented him from signing. He then indicated to Aberdeen manager <a href="Derek%20McInnes">Derek McInnes</a> that he may retire and become a coach.
International.
Maloney made 20 appearances and netted six times for <a href="Scotland%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Scotland Under 21s</a>.
Maloney made his full international debut as a half-time substitute in <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a>'s 1–0 defeat to <a href="Belarus%20national%20football%20team">Belarus</a> at <a href="Hampden%20Park">Hampden Park</a> on 8 October 2005. He scored his first international goal, a free-kick in the <a href="Svangaskard%20Stadium">Svangaskard Stadium</a> in a 2–0 victory over the <a href="Faroe%20Islands%20national%20football%20team">Faroe Islands</a> in June 2007.
Maloney scored five goals in <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202016%20qualifying%20Group%20D">UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying Group D</a>, including the winner in Scotland's home tie against the Republic of Ireland.
Coaching career.
<a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> appointed Maloney to a coaching role with their <a href="Celtic%20F.C.%20Under-20s%20and%20Academy">under-20 development squad</a> in August 2017. Maloney was added to the coaching staff of the <a href="Belgium%20national%20football%20team">Belgium national team</a> in September 2018. Later that month, he left Celtic to take the position with Belgium on a full-time basis. Maloney worked for Belgium during the delayed <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202020">UEFA Euro 2020</a> tournament, in which they lost to <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a> in the quarter-finals.
Hibernian.
Maloney was appointed manager of Scottish club <a href="Hibernian%20F.C.">Hibernian</a> in December 2021.
